utterances: Get out.
Ken, I guess we have to begin in Arkansas, where everybody thought voters would be telling Blanche Lincoln to get out.
Well, if any state was going to be the test of anti-incumbency, we thought it would be Arkansas.

Blanche Lincoln, who barely went ahead of Bill Halter in the May 18th Democratic primary, was forced into a runoff, and yet with a very important, crucial visit from Bill Clinton and also very hard-hitting ads where she attacked the Washington labor unions - you don't hear too many Democrats doing that.
No.

But the labor unions and the net roots and the left, you know, the progressives spent up to $10 million to defeat her in the runoff, but she won pretty handily, by four points, considering most of us thought she would go down to defeat.
And a big night for women elsewhere, beginning, I guess we have to say, in California.
Well, California was big.
For the first time in history - for the first time in California history, Republicans have nominees for both the governorship and the Senate seat.
The Senate seat, of course, is the one held by Barbara Boxer, and Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive at Hewlett-Packard, is the nominee there.
And for the governor's race against Jerry Brown, the former governor, will be Meg Whitman, who spent $80 million, $71 million of her own money, to win the nomination there.
And no surprises on the Democratic side.
As you said, the people we expected to be...
Well, there were--of course, Tulane is an old institution, 171 years.
It's got a great history in research, a number of Nobel laureates; many firsts.
You were talking about stem cells earlier on.
We opened the first adult stem cell center in the country.
We've got lots of studies that are critically important to the nation and the world.
Bogalusa heart study is in children what Framingham is in adults.
So...
Yeah.
Tell us about that study.
You had blood and tissue samples of that dating back how far?
Going back 30 to 40 years.
And they're all gone.
Well, they're not all gone.
We've done a lot to mitigate, so we have residuals in our freezers, which can be used for genetic testing.
We have duplicates and we have a lot of profiling.
So we haven't lost everything...
Right.
...but we sure have lost a lot.
Mm-hmm.
And...
And I would say, you know, the losses really come in four categories.
There's the damage to the first floors and basements, and we didn't have things like animals in any of those areas.
We've learned over time, because of flooding, not to do that.
But we do have labs there, and certainly for our population sciences studies, where we see participants in the community and for our clinical research, that all goes on on the first floor.
So that was a total write-off.
We just had to throw it all out.
We really worked really hard.
Our faculty were just magnificent in the immediate post-Katrina era and they managed to feed and water the animals.
So we did manage to save a lot of our animals, the important transgenic mice.
We do have a tank farm of liquid nitrogen to preserve cell lines, both clinical and research.
We have preserved a lot of equipment, but we've lost all of our freezers.
I mean, obviously we have the freezers, but the specimens are...
Right.
...largely of no use.
Everyone was disrupted.
Obviously, our international studies, which were active in about 70 countries, were minimally disrupted, but all of the administration, the brain of the university went down.
We've only recently gotten our e-mail up and working again.
So everyone was disrupted and some were incredibly disrupted.
Population sciences, clinical research, those were very, very severely disrupted.
Are you getting back online now where things are...
We're back online.
We have been working 24/7 to really get things up and going again.
And we have done a lot of mitigation and the good news is we did save a lot.
We didn't have anything dangerous occur.
We worked very early on to make sure that there would be no select agents or any dangerous agents that would get into the wrong hands.
So we now are eight weeks after the event.
We've had 400 workers in our buildings pretty much day and night and still we're not back up.
We only have power in one of our buildings.
We're planning to get our investigators back into their own research space on a staggered basis beginning in early November.
We have been very fortunate that the academic community has been there for us.
The National Institutes of Health, the NSF, they've all been magnificent throughout this.
They have helped us, allowed our investigators and our post-docs to find locations on a temporary basis.
They've helped us with extensions of funding, so they're really come through for us in a way that many others haven't and we're immensely grateful.
Well, I wish you good luck and wish you the best in getting back to work as quickly as you can.
Well, thank you.
And thank you for taking time to join...
You're welcome.
Thanks for having me on.
...with us and tell us about this.
You're welcome.
We've been talking about the state of research in New Orleans, Paul Whelton, senior vice president for health sciences at Tulane University's Health Sciences Center in New Orleans.
And now we remember an American soldier who was laid to rest today at Arlington National Cemetery.
Retired Sergeant Mark Matthews died at the age of 111.
He was the oldest living Buffalo Soldier, the name given to the men and women who served in the US military's all-black regiments.
He served along the US-Mexican border in pursuit of Mexican revolutionary Pancho Villa and was a veteran of the Second World War.
To tell us more about the exceptionally long life of Sergeant Matthews, we turn now to Joe Holley, staff writer for The Washington Post, who joins us from The Post's studio here in Washington.
Good to speak with you.
Hi, Neal.
It's nice to talk to you.
What do we know about what kind of a man Mark Matthews was?
Mark Matthews was certainly a pioneer.

I mean, he was a Buffalo Soldier beginning in the teens of the 20th century and was a soldier through his 40s, fought in World War II, if you can believe that, and apparently was deeply proud of his service, and in the years after his retirement, according to family members, he would sit on the front porch, and kids from the neighborhood would come and sit at his knee and he would tell them stories, and you can imagine they were amazing tales.
Going into Mexico after Pancho Villa with Blackjack Pershing, yeah, some pretty amazing stories.
That's right.
From that to taking care of horses for President Roosevelt when he was stationed at Ft.
Myer, Virginia, in the 1930s to fighting in the Pacific in World War II.
So he had a store of tales to tell.
And even some more recent ones.
In more recent years, he got to meet the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and secretary of State, Colin Powell.
You know, people getting paid under the table, but we all know that that is illegal.
You're supposed to report all of your taxable income, and tips are taxable.
How about this: suppose you're a kid and you are - you're going to go some place else and get a job for the summer.
Would the cost of getting to that place - like maybe being a camp counselor or something like that - would that be tax deductible?
Well, what's tax deductible is if you put your kid in a summer camp, that may count as an expense towards your child and dependant care credit.
And you can claim that credit if you put your kid in a day camp.
That's not overnight camp, but a day camp.

So you want to - you know, it's just like when you go to work during the regular school season, and you have to put them in before or after care that will allow you to work, and that can be deductible - the same thing with summer camp.
Oh, well that's a good thing to know.
Mm hmm.
And what about that, though?
Suppose you have a kid who's going off to be a camp counselor, could that child deduct from their income - could they deduct the cost of getting to the camp for the summer?
You know, you take a plane or a bus or something and...
Right.
No, not necessarily.
No. You can...
You can't?
No.
That's just a job, and just like we can't deduct when we drive to our regular jobs, you would not be able to deduct that.
Now, obviously, we go back to where we talked before about making sure they fill out their W-4 form correctly.
But the cost of going to and from work is not typically deductible for anybody.
Michelle Singletary writes the syndicated column the Color of Money.
She's also our regular guest for discussions of personal finance.
Michelle, thank you.
You're so welcome.
I want to tell you about another Houston resident.
Her name is Angie Cruz, and she works right here at our hotel north of Houston.
Yesterday, we decided to go on a drive with her.
And in the car, we were reflecting back to when we first met.
It was back on Sunday night.
There was this driving rain here.
We had just arrived in town.
We found our hotel.
Angie was working security.
She was patrolling the parking lot in a golf cart.
It was kind of scary.
You know, you saw my golf cart.
I didn't have a windshield so I was still out there soaking wet.
If I'm not out there, someone could be out there breaking into their cars.
